title: LM8UU Bearing Holder Using Single Cable Tie

description.text:
I made this so that I could better use plastic bushings on the bed of my Tronxy P802E instead of the noisy SC8UU's. If plastic bushings are misaligned slightly they will bind and cause motor skips and getting them aligned is very fussy business. These holders hold the bushing by single central cable tie which allows them to flex enough to avoid binding while holding them securely enough that there is no added wiggle to the bed. Made the switch to printed bushings much easier for me. What also made the transition to bushings work was my switch from the acrylic to an aluminum bed carriage. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2545713

My printers y stop switch touches off on the bearing block so that is why the one design has a wall on one end. That also gives them a more stable base for printing on end which gives a smoother saddle for the bushing.

I highly recommend ditching your noisy bearings for Igus or Igus style printed bearings. My prints are so smooth now! Even when my original bearings were in good shape it wasn't this nice.

I printed bearings from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1811769 as they have a nice selection of inner diameters so you can get that perfect fit. I am currently using PLA on my bed and nylon on my x carriage to see how they hold up.

Note: These bushings did require a bit more force to move than bearings even when well aligned, so I had to adjust my stepper up a bit to avoid skipped steps.

Do not lubricate with any oil or grease! I found that lubrication will increase static friction and increase skipping risk. It will make them slide easier once moving, but will be stickier when starting.

  • UPDATE Jan 19 2018
    I have tried a few different materials for printed bushings now for awhile and here are my thoughts
  • NYLON (Taulmen Bridge) This has to much "stiction" (static friction). Slides smooth once moving, but is grippy when getting started. This is probably due to its rubbery nature. My motors could not provide enough torque to avoid skips.
  • PLA This is the easiest gliding filament. Works really well. Only downside is that you do not want to run in a warm environment. I found that even 40C ambient can result in very slight deformations over time (especially if the bed is really hot). And this will eventually cause skips. 35C ambient seems to be very safe though.
  • PETG Have been using for awhile on my x axis only and it works good so far. Doesn't slide quite as easily as PLA but not that much worse. No obvious stiction. My hope is that it will handle higher ambient temperatures better than PLA, but have not had it above 35C yet as I still have PLA on my bed bushings.

Again, I am not lubricating these bushings. All wet lubes dramatically increase stiction. I did try a dry Teflon spray and that did seem to help slightly, but the effect seemed very temporary and would require reapplication every handful of hours of printing.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print on end like they load in as for smoothest surface for bushing to set on. The flatter one should also print ok flipped down.

author: Duke_S

description.text:
Nothing too special here...

I needed some feet to place my 3d printer on. I went with a 40x40mm screw spacing and 50mm square size. The screws holes are counter-bored to allow the socket head cap to fully submerge, and the feet are thick enough that there is plenty of holding power. The counter-bore allowed me to put some vibration absorbing foam under the foot, attached using double-sided adhesive dots. I poked some holes through the foam to allow the screws to be loosened if removal is required.

Screw holes are for M5 screws. I treated the edges of the feet with acetone to increase strength.

I have noticed a significant reduction in vibration noise traveling into the floor (my printer is in the second story of my house).

I used this foam: https://www.amazon.com/Du-Bro-514-Protective-Foam-Rubber/dp/B0006NATDY/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1505606380&sr=8-2&keywords=du-bro+foam

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

description.text:
This is a simple stand for a Maverick ET73 barbecue dual probe thermometer. It will fit other Maverick thermometers as well, if the thermometer is about 0.78" thick, 2.37" wide, 3.93" high, with a curved bottom and a slightly curved face. The sketchup file is attached, should you wish to make modifications.

This stand is designed as two pieces, a socket for the bottom end of the thermometer and the angled stand. I printed in ABS and used a slurry of acetone and ABS scrap as a glue to put them together. This allows for different sections to be optimized to avoid supports, and also allows picking orientations for best strength.

I printed on a Flashforge Creator Pro, using Simplify3D as the slicer. The Simplify factory file is in the uploaded files. Printing is simple: pretty much any resolution, no raft, no supports. I ran the first layer at 140% width because of the skinny footprint of the stand on the print bed, and printed the first layer pretty slow.

title: Ford Focus ST Front License Plate Bracket

description.text:
When I purchased my 2017 Ford Focus ST the dealer had not mounted the front license plate bracket. After a quick Google search revealed my state of NJ required a front license plate, I snapped the stock front bracket into the appropriate holes but did not drill any holes or used any screws to secure the bracket to the body of the car. I stood back and cringed at how the center mounted plate diminished the aggressive look of my new car. Later that day I drove about 50 miles and when I got home the stock bracket along with my license plate was gone! After waiting in line at the DMV and paying $7 for new plates, and finding no alternative brackets online, I decided to try and design my own bracket that could be fully secured, WITHOUT drilling holes in the bumper and did not take away from the look of the car. This 3D printed design does exactly that and can be installed without removing the grill.

UPDATE 10/30/17
Due to the lack of competenent parallel parkers in my community my mount has been broken three times. All three times were due to drivers hitting my car while they were parking theirs, the mount has never failed while driving or for any other reason other than a direct impact from another vehicle. All three times it was the connecting rod that snapped, no other parts were damaged and no marks were left on the car.
With this in mind I HIGHLY suggest creating a zip tie anchor. Furthermore I now keep a pair of cutters I can use to clip the zip tie in my glove box so if I ever do find the plate dangling I can take the plate + holder off until I can repair the mount. You can even go a step furthur and keep spare connecting rods and an alan key in your car to do a field repair.
I have thought about redesigning the mount to increase strength and rigidity, but I actually found these incidents enlightening as the connecting rod served as a 'break-away' part and by failing can actually prevent damage to the car. If the connecting rod was stronger, it is conceivable these impacts would have put more stress on the gril and increased the likelyhood of damaging the grill or body of the car.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

High

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Because all of the parts will be exposed to the elements I recommend printing all parts in ABS plastic to ensure none of them fail due to exposure to the sun.
I printed all my parts with 100% infill to make them as strong as possible, but if you are trying to ration your plastic you can adjust as needed. I would always go with 100% infill on the Connecting Rod as that is the weakest link in the assembly.
None of the parts require support material, but you may need to rotate them in Matter Control to orient them properly.
The License Mount is suceptible to curling up off the bed. I used a heavy amount of Elmers Glue Stick to try and prevent this, although minor curling won't prevent the mount from working.

Hardware Needed

The entire bracket can be assembled using two M3 screws and self locking nuts. I used four M3 washers as well.
To mount your license plate you will need self tapping screws that are no longer than 2cm and .5cm diameter (including the thread).
The bottom left cylindrical dome will make contact with the body of your vehicle, to prevent scratching I domed the end, but I recommend placing some rubber or felt end on it just to be safe. I used the rubber end of a cane I found at ACE, but can also be found here:
https://www.amazon.com/SoftTouch-Rubber-Leg-Tip-pieces/dp/B004672ZS8/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1505605696&sr=8-1&keywords=rubber+cane+tips
This fit nicely and I secured it with a bit of glue.

Assembly

Place the Grill Plug in the grill hole indicated in the photos and use two Grill Hooks on the top and the bottom to reach around and secure the plug in place.
Insert the connecting rod into the Grill Plug so the screw holes line up. If you are confused which way make sure the end that is flat passes through the Grill Plug.
Use one M3 screw along with two M3 washers to secure all four pieces together. You may find it easier to pass the screw through the bottom opposed to the top. Use a M3 self locking nut to secure it.
Mount your license plate to the License Mount using self tapping screws, and place your rubber or felt tip of choice on the appropriate corner.
Slide the License Mount on to the connecting rod and secure it with one M3 screw, two M3 washers, and a M3 self locking nut.

A Special Note

Just to be safe I attached a zip tie through the grill and anchored it directly to the License Mount. This is just an extra precaution in case the Connecting Rod snaps, that way I won't lose the License Plate and have to wait in line at the DMV to get new ones.

Works very well and accomplished exactly what I set out to do. The roads in my area are pretty bad but the bracket has held up fine. The rubber cane tip I am using has not fallen off or left any scuffs on the paint. The plate only obstructs the left most column of the open grill holes and those are not even the ones directly in front of the radiator so air flow is not obstructed. I don't use automated car washes but that may be something to watch out for.

This bracket should allow you to use a license plate frame of your choice, currently I am not using one but may get one in the future. There is a bit of flimsyness in the bracket since it only has one mounting point, my only concern would be that adding additional weight to the mount could put more stress on the Connecting Rod and make this worse.

In the future I may edit the Connecting Rod to include an open channel which I could slide three stainless steel rods through for added strength and rigidity

title: LM8UU-Style Bearing / Bushing Holder (Friction Hold / 2 Part) (Endstop Compatible)

description.text:
A two part holder for an LM8UU type bearing.

There are now two variations. The first relies on screwing the holder into the plastic. The second allows you to insert 4 M4 nuts and screw the holder in using those instead.

You'll want to use 2x Holder_Std or 2x Holder_Nuts to hold most bearings. If a bearing holder is required to trigger an endstop then you can use 1xStop_End or 1xNuts_Stop_End on the side that needs to trigger. It has has a more standard profile in the first couple of millimetres to serve this purpose.

I am currently using these for the Y carriage of my 3D printer (an Anet A8 - now AM8)

18/02/2018 - I've now been using the nut based variant in my printer on the y axis for several weeks and on prints as long as 24 hours. I was inspired to make this variation following a request on my other bearing holder design.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

PLA 0.2 or 0.24mm, ABS 0.16mm. (0.4mm nozzle)

Infill:

30-35% but feel free to experiment.

Notes:

3 outer perimeters at 0.4mm nozzle size recommended for the version without nuts to give you enough material to cut a solid thread into.

2 outer perimeters for the Nut holding version

It is suggested to tap the holes in the bottom with a 4mm thread to ensure a secure fit. It's possible to just force the screw into the part when installing but this would risk stripping the hole leaving you with a hole which is then too large for the screw to grip. (In a pinch you can slide a slither of plastic or two into the sides of a hole and hold them in place while inserting the screw - this will quite often hold sufficiently in the short term.)

2 M4 nuts (hex) per piece required for the Nuts parts so 4 M4 per bearing.
Far more boolean operations than were strictly necessary - designed using OpenSCAD.

remixed_from.author: nskalsky
remixed_from.title: Ergonomic Stand for Macbook (Laptop) CNC/Cutting Tool-Path

description.text: The other post has STL files and comments were posted asking for svg file. So here ya go

This is an add-on accessory for the totally awesome Vorpal Combat Hexapod, If you haven't seen that yet, then this thing won't make sense, so visit there first:

  • Thing 2513566: Vorpal Combat Hexapod

I made this all open source and respectfully ask you to consider supporting the project. We successfully funded on Kickstarter with hundreds of kits sold, and now we have our own store. We have more than just the Hexapod electronics, we have all kinds of things useful for small robotics and other projects:
Vorpal Robotics Store with Hexapod Kits

  • IMPORTANT: If you opt-in to receive our store monthly newsletters you'll automatically be enrolled in a monthly prize drawing, first prize is a $100 store credit and there are lots of other smaller prizes too! Sign up for newsletters here: Vorpal Store Newsletter List

Why do I need this for the Hexapod?

These are name plates for the hexapod. These can be used to distinguish teams during competitions, or just add a little fun to the project.

Installing the Magnets

Each design has a recepticle for a 10mm diameter by 3mm thick magnet. The magnet should be installed with the South pole exposed. In our kits, north pole is marked with a dimple. Magnets on the robot should have dimple showing, magnets on accessories that stick to the robot should have dimples hidden. Pretty easy.

The magnets, if they are the correct size, snap in. You may be able to do this with your fingrs, or you may need to gently use piiers to force them in that last little bit. But for me at least, they never fall out. If they fall out for you I'm sure a drop of superglue or hot glue will solve the problem.
Print two of these and you have s sturdy tablet stand. you can change angles on it as well.

I used ABS with 1 layer and 100% infill. also you will need 1/8 drill rod to connect the hole contraption.
use a 1/8" drill to make the holes a little bit rounded an bur free.

The basic tsuba is a really simple design for equiping your bokken and protect your hands when training. I recommend using at least 80% infill or various shells.

Enjoy and keep on training!

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

80

This is an add-on accessory for the totally awesome Vorpal Combat Hexapod, If you haven't seen that yet, then this thing won't make sense, so visit there first:

  • Thing 2513566: Vorpal Combat Hexapod

Check out the Hexapod Intro Features Video

I made this all open source and respectfully ask you to consider supporting the project. We successfully funded on Kickstarter with hundreds of kits sold, and now we have our own store. We have more than just the Hexapod electronics, we have all kinds of things useful for small robotics and other projects:
Vorpal Robotics Store with Hexapod Kits

  • IMPORTANT: If you opt-in to receive our store monthly newsletters you'll automatically be enrolled in a monthly prize drawing, first prize is a $100 store credit and there are lots of other smaller prizes too! Sign up for newsletters here:
  • Vorpal Store Opt-in for Prize Drawing

Why do I need this for the Hexapod?

OK, now that you understand, this thing is three different eye decorations for the Vorpal Combat Hexapod.

The eye decorations may seem trivial, but they are an integral part of the project. When the eyes are installed in the right place, they clearly indicate where the "front" of the robot is and so are crucial for orienting the person using the gamepad.

Also, trust me on this, people respond much more positively to the robot if it has the eyes on. Without the eyes: creepy spidery thing. With the eyes: Cute cartoon-like thing.

Installing the Magnets

Each design has a recepticle for a 10mm diameter by 3mm thick magnet. The magnet should be installed with the South pole exposed. In our kits, north pole is marked with a dimple. Magnets on the robot should have dimple showing, magnets on accessories that stick to the robot should have dimples hidden. Pretty easy.

The magnets, if they are the correct size, snap in. You may be able to do this with your fingrs, or you may need to gently use piiers to force them in that last little bit. But for me at least, they never fall out. If they fall out for you I'm sure a drop of superglue or hot glue will solve the problem.

Give Us More Eyes!

If you develop compatible eyes, please let me know and we will link to them off our website! If we're super impressed, we may even send you a Vorpal Combat Hexapod T-shirt.

To be compatible, make a round hole 10.8mm in diameter on the back (where the nose is). it should be 3mm deep. See our OnShape project for exact details. You don't need to use OnShape for your contributions, anything you want.

title: "Smooth Mount" - Guitar/Ukulele Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The STL file is sized for a Ukulele. Scale to around 150% for a guitar in your slicer or printer. I suggest printing the tall version since it will all your Ukulele to sit with the strings out (looks nicer).

A very solid Ukulele/Guitar wall mount. It's simple and elegant and gets the job done very well. I have a bunch of these printed and they work great! For a guitar you may need to play with the size. I set it to 150% scale for a guitar, but you will find the best size for your 'axe'.

The problem with printing something to carry weight is that most are designed from items that were not 3D printed, so when we print them they are not as strong as plastic molds or metal molds. This is designed to have a sturdier shape so that you don't have to worry about it breaking.

Suggested outer layer thickness is 2mm with at least 25% infill.

Suggested Material: PETG or Nylon. ABS will work well too if you have a handle on the warping factor. This is meant to hold weight so PLA is probably not your best bet. Maybe PLA if it's at 100% infill?

comments.text: Did you print this as the STL is oriented (standing upright, with a lot of supports), or rotated 90° so it rests on the wall plate? While the latter seems like an obvious choice, I do ask as so often correct layer orientation is crucial for the robustness of a print, so I'd rather ask beforehand whether that orientation of the design was by purpose :) Thanks a lot for it, it looks sturdy and good!
comments.author: heinzdrei

comments.text: Print it with the flat base on the build plate. The orientation in the design software is different than most slicers, there isn't a universal orientation between programs. You could try printing it on it's top/bottom edge which would make it stronger, but this shouldn't be necessary.

description.text: Hotshoe Diffuser Clip for Canon EOS Rebel XT SLR Camera

1) Print both parts
2) Use the adhesive of your choice to bond them together. If you use ABS, acetone works perfectly
3) Pop open the flash on your camera
4) Insert the part into the hotshoe
5) Insert a card of your choice (white, reflective, translucent, colored, etc.)
6) Snap away and enjoy!

comments.text: Unfortunately, slipping this in the hotshoe disables the Rebel XT's flash, so it doesn't work like I wanted to. title: Armattan Chameleon GoPro HERO5 Session mount

description.text:
I got tired of having to use a strap to hold down my camera mount to this frame. The props often cut them or they were torn away in a crash forcing me to search for the GoPro many times over. I came up with this design from another design : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2173011 by Tbrady420. I didn't like the sides open on his design so i closed it up, changed the front a little so you wont see the mount in super-view, exposed the mic, and created the opening from the rear where the battery will prevent any ejections in harsh crashes.

You'll need to remove the camera mount top plate and slide it into the camera mount. Then mount the camera mount and top plate to the frame BEFORE you insert the GoPro or else you'll have issues reaching the screw heads with your driver. The flexible material allows the mount to be altered to access the screw heads while the camera isn't inserted. inserting the gopro is easier than removing it and you should angle the frame top plate to its lowest setting when inserting and removing the gopro.

description.text:
This measuring jig fits between the top of the z-motor mounting plate and the bottom of the x mounts. When it fits about the same on both sides you should be good to go!

My printer as it is setup up currently rarely needs any adjustment if the bed is well leveled once. I just do a quick 4 second check with the jig after homing and about 10% of the time I may need to turn a z motor a click or two. Good enough for me!

I feel I should note that one simple thing that I changed on my Tronxy P802E that made a BIG BIG improvement on getting a consistent bed level was to replace the horrible acrylic bed undercarriage with a solid aluminum one. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2545713

The whole idea of auto bed leveling is to ajust the first layer to make the bed level thereafter so the artifects you have seen won't have been caused by a slightly warped bed.
Everyone is entitled to thier own opinion but don't discard or discredit what you have not tried.
comments.author: keredg

comments.text:
Keredg,
Thanks for the constructive criticism. You make good points. I changed my wording to not be so dismissive of auto bed leveling.
comments.author: keredg

comments.text: Auto bed leveling is nothing to do with Z axis hight being equal, some beds come warped and are not flat so auto leveling is a must.I just use a small bit of dowel rod to level my Z axis
comments.author: keredg

comments.text:
Yeah, i was probably a bit to stong in dissing auto bed leveling. Compensating for warped beds is a major advantage of auto bed leveling. It also allows you to hit print with a little less fuss regardless. I am still may go that route on my next printer. Guess that could make me a looser. ;-) But my current printer is good enough without it that I wont bother. The bed is flat and only the dual z motor thing causes me any issues and thus my measuring stick.
I think that one should fix/replace a warped bed instead relying on compensation too heavily. I've seen images of some odd print artifacts caused by it. The printer manufacturers like it because it allows them to get away with lower quality beds and keeps prices a bit lower. It is still largely an electronic kludge for mechanical deficiencies in my opinion.

This is a Mech Skull for your enjoyment.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Bat Fridge Magnet

Search "wslab" for more designs.

The stock Trigger in the Swiffer Bissel Steamboost mop pivots on weak nubs that wear down over time, causing it to become dislodged and no longer function. To remedy this, a roommate drove a screw through theirs, which is a good start, except that the existing thin plastic walls can't handle the strain of being forced against the screw with each pull and will inevitably blow apart. My solution was to model a replacement trigger with the hole already there, so that it will be reinforced when printed.

To make this work, you may need to grind a bit off the back sides (pictured). You'll also want a screw that fits snuggly in the trigger itself so that it doesn't shift and fall out. But the holes you drill in the handle itself should give the screw some room to move slightly forward and backwards, as the trigger will still want to pivot on its corner and the axle hole will rotate around that pivot point.

description.text:
I have a custom hot-end mount on my machine, so I needed a way to mount a cooling fan. I don't actually use it while printing as I have never found a good use for cooling fans during printing. However, it is good for cooling down a print if I am overly eager to pull it off the bed.

The duct provides a very good blade of air without slowing down the fan, as many ducts do. It can be pivoted around the x axis (rotated around X). The mount was designed for M3 screws but drill whatever holes you need as long as you print it with enough perimeters. The holes to mount the fan are deliberately small so that they can be cleanly drilled to the right diameter, and tapped if desired. I "tapped" mine lazily by just screwing in some screws I had.

The mount portion is very small so that it can be reprinted quickly and with little plastic in the event that it breaks or whatever.

I'm posting this in the hope that it can be useful to someone.

title: Magnetic dial indicator mount for i3 Plus

description.text:
This is a dial test indicator mount that uses magnets to produce a consistent down-force on the rod. Together with the width of the mount, this means that the dial indicator is always held flat against the rods, and you can lift the indicator's spindle without affecting the alignment of the set-up.

This mount fits onto the X-axis rods of the i3 family of printers, assuming that the rods are 8 mm OD and 45 mm apart. I use a dial indicator for tramming the Z axis and leveling the bed.

Parts needed

  • 1× dial test indicator.
  • 1× Dial indicator holder.stl. If your dial indicator has a straight tab ~18 mm wide, use the holder (analog). If your dial indicator has a tapered tab that is ~17 mm at the base, use the holder (digital).
  • 1× 1/4-20 UNC screw, 25 mm long.
  • 1× 1/4-20 nut.
  • 2× 6×2 mm neodymium magnet.

Assembly

  1. Attach the dial indicator to the printed mount with the screw and nut.
  2. Hang the mount on your X axis rods.
  3. Place one of the magnets on top of a magnet hole above the top rod. It will snap to the correct polarity.
  4. Remove the mount + magnet from the printer together. Hammer the magnet into the hole.
  5. Repeat for the second magnet.

author: WaveSupportApparatus

title: Mine Truck v3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had a mind to make a few more Mine trucks using my earlier design. I did this, but soon grew bored with sticking together the buffer bits and also the extra time required to glue the side assemblies together. So I redesigned it to be easier to assemble and generally quicker to build. While this design looks the same, it is somewhat different.

The front buffers are now a single print. The side panels are now a single print too. This means that there is a little bit more fall off around some of the overhung parts on the buffers, but this in minimal.

Like the previous version, this is just the chassis. Decks and whatever else is going to be mounted on it are simply scratch built. There are some other very cool model railway bits and pieces on Thingiverse that may lend themselves quite nicely to being adapted to go on this chassis.

The overall dimensions are 65mm wide x 120mm long x 32mm tall. The track gauge is about 38mm. The wheels have reasonably wide flanges and so can ride on rails up to about 40mm between rail centrelines.

Things you will need in addition to the printed bits;

  • 2 x Ø4mm rods of some sort for the axles. These are cut to 55mm long. I used dowel.
  • Glue. I use an epoxy glue, but anything without too much flexibility will work.

Have Fun

description.text: This roller is design to fit the stock filament holder that comes with Anet printers. The length of it is 120mm and the overall outside diameter is 35mm. It's designed to have 608 bearings (8mm x 22mm x 7mm, typical fidget spinner bearing) pressed into it by hand which also fits onto the threaded rod that comes with the holder. It give much smoother payout over the threaded rod or any stationary shaft you may use. You could also used this with home brew filament holders or possibly other manufactures' filament holders.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10

Lay a 608 bearing on a flat, sturdy surface and press shaft into place. Lay second bearing onto the same surface and press in the second bearing into opposite end of shaft. Put threaded rod that comes with the printer into the bearings and place your favorite filament onto roller shaft and onto holder.
Had 608 bearing and didn't like how the filament roll sat into the holder. Now the filament payout is much smoother and easier on the extruder and X-axis.

print_settings.Notes:: Print in the orientation that they come in as.   Petg worked good for me but should work in other materials about as well.

title: Groucho Duke's 29mm high power rocket launch tower
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3d printed end support for a launch tower for 29mm high power rockets. This is still a work in progress, but I've done one flight with a 29mm minimum diameter rocket flying with a CTI I224 rocket motor. This is designed to fit the Madcow Go Devil 29 and similarly sized rockets.

I've done several flights with this with minimum diameter 29mm rockets and CTI I224 motors. None of the parts show any wear & everything works great. You can see a video of my first 29mm min-diameter rocket CTI I224 launch here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Np2yk-4uS3s

Bill of materials:
Approx 1kg of PETG or similar filament. This is what I used: http://amzn.to/2y7Z0zs
4x #10 1-14" machine screws
8x #10 washers
4x #10 lock nuts
6x 1/4-20 x 4" lag bolts
1x 1010 launch rail
2x aluminum extruded L
3x 3/4" EMT conduit
Adhesive backed Teflon tape. Here's what I used: http://amzn.to/2wn9Hlc

Contruction:

  • Print 2 of the parts (takes approx 30 hours each plus about 0.4kg of filament)
  • Sand/file/buff/machine the EMT conduit to remove any bumps that would damage your rocket
  • Test fit the 3d printed parts on the 1010 rail, EMT conduit & extruded L
  • Trim extruded L and/or EMT conduit to fit. Deburr the ends so they'll slide onto the 3d printed parts (For the 4' extruded L I used, trimming the EMT conduit to 44-3/16" worked well.)
  • Sand/file/adjust the 3d printed parts as required
  • Slide both 3d printed parts on the 1010 rail
  • Screw the 1/4" lag bolts into place in the holes where the EMT conduit mounts
  • Tape one side of each EMT conduit with the PFTE/Teflon adhesive tape.
  • Support one end of the EMT conduit with something to keep them level and slide into one of the 3d printed parts. Make sure the Teflon tape faces where the rocket will go. I used some car washing sponges to prop up the EMT. Repeat for all 3 EMT conduit pieces.
  • Slide the other 3d printed part and EMT conduit into place. Depending on the fit, this may take some force. Use extreme caution not to damage your 3d printed parts when assembling the tower. If you damage your 3d printed parts, throw them away and print new ones. Do not use damaged parts in your rocket launch tower!
  • Once all three EMT conduit pieces are in place, slide the extruded L pieces into place. Drill 3/16" holes through the L using the holes in the 3d printed parts to guide you.
  • Use #10 machine screws, washers & nuts to attach the L pieces to the 3d printed parts.
  • Test fit your rockets, inspect, & go fly!

Printer:

Folgertech Prusa i3 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.28mm

Infill:

90%

Notes:

This was printed with PETG. If you make a high power rocket launch tower using this part, you need to use a high temp material that can withstand the heat of a rocket motor. Whatever you do, don't use a material like PLA that deforms easily with heat.

Infil is varied to provide strength where it's needed. Printing this at low infil will make it weak. Weak rocketry parts are horribly dangerous, so don't skimp. The middle section is printed at 90% and the top & bottom sections are printed at 40%. With the settings below, it'll take almost a full 1kg roll of PETG to print 2 of these parts. Here are the infil percentages, based on height within the object:
0mm - 40mm: 40%
40mm - 60mm: 90%
60mm - 100mm: 40%

title: Primbal V3 - 3 Axis Brushless Gimbal for Yi/GoPro

description.text:
Primbal V3 is here. Over a year ago I released the original Primbal, one of the only 3D printable brushless gimbal designs. Since then I have been experimenting and revising the design to make Primbal even better.

Primbal V3 implements stronger, stiffer arms that make the gimbal more resistant to vibrations. The camera mount is also more rigid, with a system to hold the camera from both the back and front. Additionally, there are now four different isolator options to suite your fancy. The result is a more robust, versatile gimbal to bring you silky smooth video.

This gimbal is composed of 14 printed parts that are all printer friendly. All STLs are in the proper printing position, no reorienting required. All three axis (pitch, roll, yaw) are fully adjustable to perfectly balance the gimbal. This gimbal is designed to best perform with a Xiaomi Yi, but it can be modified to fit GoPros and other similar action cams.

Specs:

Parts:
14 Printed

Hardware:
2 x M1.6 Bolt and Nut 12mm (M2 works as well)
8 x M2 Bolt 8mm
2 x M2 Nut
4 x M3 Bolt 4mm
2 x M3 Bolt 6mm

Motors:
2804 size for yaw (35mm diameter)
2206/2804 size for roll
2206 size for pitch (28mm diameter)

Confirmed to Fit:
Hobbyking 2804-210Kv
Hobbyking 2206-140Kv
Rctimer GBM2804
Might Fit:
Quanum 2208
DYS BGM2208

Controller:
Any 3 axis brushless gimbal controller to externally control the gimbal. I recommend a Storm32 board.

Weight:
Approximately 250g with camera, 175g without

Range of Motion
Pitch: -90 +90
Roll: -45 +45
Yaw: Depends on wiring

Balancing:

Balancing on the roll and yaw axes is done through loosening the bolts holding the arms to the roll/yaw motors and sliding the bolt spacer along the adjustment slot. For the pitch axis a similar thing is done with the pitch adjuster to adjust up and down. To adjust the pitch axis back, add spacers between the bolts holding the camera frame to the pitch adjuster. The Xiaomi Yi should balance perfectly on the pitch axis without any adjustment to forward/back.

Different Motors/Parts:

GoPro Hero 3/4 models should fit the gimbal with minor modification. Newer GoPro models may need more care.

If you need the design modified to fit a different gimbal motor or part, then let me know! I can modify the design for your needs. No guarantees though as there is only so much you can do without the physical parts in hand.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print the bolt spacers, camera bar, camera clip, and pitch adjuster at 0.1mm.
The rest of the parts I recommend to print at 0.2mm.

Glueing:
To facilitate a printer friendly design, some parts have to be glued together. Super glue (CA) works best.

Glue the two halves of the tube hooks together. A brad inserted in between will add extra strength and help line up the pieces.

Glue the tube hooks to the lower isolator plate.

Glue the camera clip to the pitch adjuster.

This is a remix of the 3Dmakernoob generic temperature tower. I redesigned them to work within the Worksteel/Sunlu, 3D Solutech, Hatchbox, and Tianse recommended temperature ranges for their PLA filaments (190C-220C, 180C-210C, 190C-210C). I added levels so there would be a broader range available for analysis. I'm sure you could use these tower for other PLAs as well. Each level is a 5 degree drop in temp and the temp each level is printed at is marked on the side of the tower. The following are the heights of each level so you know where to adjust the temperature in your slicer:
base and first level: 0mm - 16.46mm
second level: 16.46mm - 29.92mm
third level: 29.92mm - 43.38mm
fourth level: 43.48mm - 56.84mm
fifth level: 56.84mm - 70.3mm
sixth level: 70.3mm - 83.76mm
top level: 83.76mm - 97.22mm

After ensuring my bed is level, the axis are in sync, and the extruder is putting out the correct amount of filament, I like to run this test as the first model on a new roll of filament. Once I determine the best temperature for that specific roll, I write the temp it runs best at on the side of the roll so I know what to set my slicer at when using that particular filament.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

10

author: iZe

title: Qidi Tech X-One Logitech C270 camera mount

description.text:
This thing is a fairly simple camera mount to get a Logitech C-270 to sit on the bed of a Qidi Tech X-One for recording/streaming prints. I built this model from scratch after my iPhone idea failed.

This keeps the camera aimed right at the middle of the bed and gets a good amount of the build area in each shot. Not bad for a $20 camera and 1.5 hours of printing.

The C-270 has to be disassembled from its included monitor mount to fit, but the peg and screw from that fit perfectly into this model to secure it. You may also need to take the camera apart to manually dial in the focus as it comes locked for a longer shot.

I recommend printing in ABS or PETG to avoid it warping under the heat the bed puts out.

Version 2 allows you to mount on the side or the front. Front mounting will cause it to stick out of the enclosure.

Made to press in the outer bearing (6803) of almost any Campagnolo freehub design. This bearing is prone to getting loose/shot, especially if you live in a wet climate, as there is no outer seal.

Replacing it is not difficult, as one can carefully hammer out this bearing using a flatblade screwdriver, and hammer a new one back in, using a 2 Euro coin. However, if you want to be a bit more sophisticated about things, you can use a bearing press. This particular design helps because it centers the sleeve between the outer and inner bearing of the freehub when pressing the bearing in.

Combine with a piece of M10 / M8 threaded rod, and some nuts. The recession on the bottom of the design holds a washer with an outer diameter of 20mm.

1. Get 40mm cooling fan with small round motor board, which is capable of running on two 2032 coin cells.
  2. Remove the fan frame and the blades. Spinner frame is made for a fan with 25mm motor board diameter.
  3. Remove a stopper ring that holds the fan axis under the sticker.
  4. Arrange wires and coin cells, solder a small 4x9mm switch. Use hot glue gun to secure the motor and the switch. it would be good to glue couple of bolts near the switch to balance the coin cells mass.
  5. Fasten frame halves with three 2x6mm screws.
  6. Put caps. Glue the top cap, widen or deepen the hole in the bottom cap if necessary.

Spinner frame prints better upside down for me.

title: Spinning Coaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Spinning Coasters are just for fun... but great for people who like to fidget, displaying (both sides of) scale models and lots more...

Well printed Spinning Coasters should spin easily / freely. The idea is not to spin them fast (like a fidget spinner) but slowly rotate... just for fun. However, they are great as a display stand for your favourite 3D prints, and scale models.

Good build plate adhesion and accurate / precise printing is very important as flat, smooth and clean surfaces are required for smooth, low resistance spinning.

Each Spinning Coaster requires a base and top to be printed. The three sizes provided are 80 / 90 / 100mm in diameter. This range provides a coaster or stand to accommodate a wide range of 'things to spin' for display or just to fidget with. Just download the corresponding base and top then print...

This is an easy print on well set up machines. Spinning Coasters look great printed in any color... have fun with them!

No support is required. Make sure the contact surfaces are smooth and lubricated with a light silicone lubricant for best results.

Please refer to the images and print settings for additional information... and post images of your Spinning Coasters in use for other members to see!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

description.text:
My first made from scratch thing. I just bought a Zuk Z2 Pro phone, only to find out that there isn't much of a fanbase for the phone, and since it isn't popular, not a lot of cases are available. And since there are absolutely none available to print out, I fashioned this basic, somewhat crude case, that works alright. It holds the phone quite well, and seem sturdy. If anything, it might serve well as a template at least. My printer was a bit rough on it when printing it out, and the pictures I took do not reflect the depth of the case. I designed this in Google Sketchup, Wings3D and TinkerCAD, and I used the Windows 3D builder as a intermediary between programs. I hope to make some prettier cases soon, since I really like this phone, and it really doesn't get the attention that it deserves. xD

title: Rotating display table - USB powered, with light

description.text:
160 mm diameter rotating display table; to present/show-off products or things. USB powered motor and light. Please read assembly instructions before building -- left as "work in progress" because of the mechanical assembly process (but if you've built a 3D printer, this shouldn't be too challenging). Power from anything other than a charger or powerbank at your own risk.

[ UPDATE 19/09/17: Added zipped IGES CAD files and turntable V2 STL ]

Assembly:
1) Print the large base (large flat side down)

2) Print the large turntable/worm-gear (a large flat side down)

3) Check the fit of the turntable to the base. The base's central post may have a nub to be trimmed at one quadrant (if your retract on layer change isn't sufficient). The turntable should spin smoothly. Don't install a screw yet, remove the turntable.

4) Print the motor spacer; either GM 20 or 130 version. The GM20 is for a gear-head motor that will provide a more suitable RPM. The worm stage gives ~ 150:1 reduction ... so a 300 RPM gear-head motor will provide about 2 RPM at the table.

6V, 300 RPM: http://www.ebay.com/itm/DC3V-6V-12V-N20-Micro-Speed-Reduction-Gear-DC-Motor-with-Metal-Gearbox-Wheel-New-/172018005599?var=&hash=item280d12765f:m:mCbH1jM0wwRJc-lzsdrwl6w

5) Mount the motor to the base using M3 x 5 screws (3X). The screws are essentially self-tapping.

6) Hack a USB cable to power the motor (red and black wires, model rendering incorrectly shows green). Before soldering the wires, check that the motor spins clockwise (looking into the shaft).

Example of USB cable hack: http://www.instructables.com/id/Really-REALLY-Easy-USB-Motor/

This USB light is inexpensive and we'll use one later; you could buy two and hack one for the cable.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Flexible-USB-LED-Light-Lamp-for-Computer-Keyboard-Reading-PC-Laptop-Notebook-LT-/182190927305?hash=item2a6b6cedc9:g:UcIAAOSwhOVXdhft

7) Print the worm (STL is mislabeled as wormgear). There's a monolithic STL and two half files. The halves worked better for me (no supports, no bed adhesion, slow speed). Print the halves at the same time (rotate one so both flats are down). The tippy-top is thin thin, so if you have a part cooler, you may get better parts than mine. Super glue the halves together ... you can (probably should) use the base as a gluing fixture to ensure lateral alignment. It is critical that the halves are well aligned.

8) Mount the worm to the motor (super/CA glue if needed). You may need to uninstall the motor to mount the worm.

9) Smooth out the worm. It is critical for the worm to be smooth. I plugged the USB cable into a charger -- essentially making a tiny lathe -- and used small files to smooth both the inner surface and outer diameter.

10) Print and install the rollers. I had better results using the half STL and super/CA gluing halves. Printed with larger diameter flat down. 7 complete rollers in total. Snap the rollers into the base and spin each one ... they loosen up after a couple turns.

11) Print five legs and install them with M3 x 5 screws. Print standing up (a flat side down). The machine screws should be effectively self-tapping.The rubber feet below can be added too.

http://www.ebay.com/itm/100-Pcs-0-3-Self-Adhesive-Rubber-Feet-Round-Door-Bumpers-Buffer-Pad-Protector/192129706293?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

12) Print the washer and install the turntable/worm gear using a M3 x 5. The turntable should spin clockwise when the motor is powered. If the turntable/worm-gear chatters or rises at the worm, then one of the two isn't smooth and needs to be filed. The "gear police" part shouldn't be needed. [ UPDATE 19/09/17: added V2 of the turntable for increased mounting hole clearance and worm clearance ]

13) Print the display table (large flat down) and rest it atop the turntable/wormgear.

14) Print the USB cable brackets oriented with an edge down. If you used a regular/small USB cable for the motor, you'll need one small bracket. Install the USB light with a M3 X 8 screw. Install the bracket for the motor's USB cable using one M3 X8 screw as well.

https://youtu.be/ntqrUvoIp3o

https://youtu.be/QXLqqfMkZFA

This is an enclosure for a FC22 gas/smoke detector I intend to us in my printer.
The detector I use is this type made for detecting smoke, CO2, benzene ...
Always check the marking on the sensor itself. The type of the print is always FC-22. It is just a different sensor. See picture.
I did some tests with it and the thing works fine.
To be mounted on a 2020-beam somewhere in the top part of the printer. My printer si fully closed, so the smallest amount of smoke will stay in the top compartment and since the detector will be there ...
Goal is to switch off all power electronics (heaters) when detecting smoke and eventually having an alarm connected to it.
For those driving their high power (lot of amps ) beds directly from the controller : mount one in the electronics enclosure!
The housing and the mount have a tight fit and the PCB is fully supported from both sides.
When using a translucent filament, the LEDs (Power and alarm) are visible from the outside.

This one is printed in PETG with a 0,6mm nozzle and 0,2mm layers.

title: Smartphone Holder Bed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey, I took this Thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2281088 and changed some features, so that it fits my needs a bit more. The design was made in Fusion 360.

The opening is 13x78mm and 154mm deep. I designed it for a Samsung Galaxy S8 but any other smartphone should fit in as well. It is intended that the Smartphone fits in completely so that it can't be damageed by a pushed-out pillow or an arm etc.

For easier removal of the smartphone from the holder i have added 2 handle holes at the upper side and one more gap at the bottom, so the smartphone can be pushed up a bit from the underside.

I have added several sizes for different bed frames - 20mm, 35mm, 50mm, 60mm, 65mm, 70mm, 76mm (Ikea MALM-bed series), 80mm. If it doesn't fit, you can customize the size by scale it a bit up or down in your 3D-Printing-Software.

Any other small items can be stored in as well.

If you have any suggestions or tips feel free to let me know.

Have fun with the design.

UPDATE 17.09.2017: I made the walls 5mm thick, so that it is easier to print and has more stability

title: Monoprice Mini Delta E3D Hotend Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
REVISION: The screw holes that hold the front to the effector were a little large and my M3 screws weren't getting a good bite. I've shrunk the holes some, so that should fix any problems attaching it.

I wanted to make a mount for a E3D style hotend while still using as much of the stock effector plate as possible. I also wanted a separate cooling fan, one that I could turn on and off, when printing with temperature sensitive filament. This is the result. Took longer than I had hoped, though that largely reflects my weak Fusion 360 skills more than any difficulty associated with the project.

Assembly is fairly straightforward. Uses one 30mm fan, one 40mm fan, two 16-18mm M3 screws and nuts to attach the front and back together, assorted M3 screws for the fans, and 3 low profile M3 to attach the front mount to the effector plate (I'd recommend reusing the ones from the stock hotend mount). It uses a V6 style heatsink, though the aluminum heating block it's designed around is a V5, which I recycled from the stock hotend. I don't think you'll be able to fit a V6 aluminum block under the mount, but to be honest I didn't try, so it may be possible if you're determined.

Future versions may include a fang-style cooling fan, once I get better at Fusion 360. Let me know what you think of it in the comments section. I've included the files for front, back and a blank back if you would like to experiment with alternate fans.

Printer:

Orb Weaver (Custom Crane-Style)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Best results on the front were when I turned it upside down. Uses lots of support, but the print comes out looking much nicer. The rear I rotated 60° with the fan mount flat on the print surface. I printed it in Makergeeks Raptor PLA because of its heat resistance, but I would recommend printing in ABS or PETG if you don't have any Raptor PLA; it is a hotend mount and will likely want some heat resistance. Tried printing at 60mm/s and 40mm/s, and the 40mm/s version came out much better, with a much easier time removing the supports.
Sliced with Cura 15

comments.text: How did you hook up both fans?

comments.text: I split the power for the fan into two lines, with a JST connector so I can disconnect the cooling fan when printing PETG and other filaments that don't like cooling. I'm looking to wire in a switch or a POT at some point, but haven't gotten around to looking into it. As far as I know, there isn't a way to enable the cooling fan on the board. Doesn't mean there isn't one; just means I don't know how.

title: Ibanez RG1570 Prestige (2007) back-plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Back-plate for a 2007 Ibanez RG1570 Prestige. Might work on other RGs and/or other years. Not sure. Designed at 138.85mm x 85.7mm dimensions.

My original back-plate has been falling apart over the years, mostly breaking around the screw holes. Figure it must happen to others with this guitar. If those people happen to have a 3D printer, then they've got a replacement in about 2 hours.

Also included is a modification that would be useful if you installed a Tremol-No locking bridge (which you should). It opens up access to be able to engage and disengage it without having the plate off.

Super specific design and print, but that's what 3D printing is about.

Edit: V2 models have very slightly larger screw holes on the back end.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

15%-20%

Notes:

Fusion 360 appears to output stl's standing up instead of flat. You'll generally need to rotate +-90 degrees along the x axis.

Recommended to print upside down (larger part of the screw holes face down). The beveled edge prints much better in that orientation. Also the screw holes seem to print better at this angle and the outer face gets a nicer finish.

Prints ok at .15, but looks really pro at a .1 res (at least once it gets to the beveled edges and screw holes) with a minimum of 4 top and bottom layers. Only takes about 2 hours.

A cyclonic dust filter I use for extracting dust on my homebrew CNC milling machine. I was surprised how efficient it is, I don't need any additional filtering! :)
It is based on the excellent Bill Pentz's plans.
The design has 5 parts: the cylindrical part of the cyclone, the conical part of the cyclone, the dust collecting receptacle, the vacuum connection with grille to insert a filter mat and adapter for flexible vacuum hose (you need 2 of these). All parts are connected together using bayonett-type connectors so you can take them apart and clean everything.
You could also use a plastic bucket instead of the receptacle - in this case, print the bucket adaptor instead of the receptacle and screw it on the bucket lid.
The parts are designed to be printed on any 3D printer with 20x20x20 cm build area and the clearances are big enough for fast printing.

Printer:

Extremely modded Craftbot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

10% or 0% (the conical piece)

Notes:

Print one part of each of the larger pieces and two flexible hose adapters.
If you trust your printer, the cyllindrical part, the receptacle and the vacuum connection can be printed with 1mm walls and minimal (10% or less) infill. If you usually have problems with print quality and/or strength, use 1,5mm walls and some more infill (not more than 15%, though). Turn the cylindrical part on it's head to save on supports. The conical part can be printed with zero infill. These measures will save you a lot of material and print time.
The vacuum hose adaptor should be printed using normal infill and medium quality (0,2mm).
Supports are needed for all parts.
You can use any material that prints well. You might use transparent PLA or PET to see if there are material blockages, but it's not really needed, it never happenned to me.

Clean up prints, pay special attention to the the bayonett parts, they won't fit otherwise. The bayonetts will be a bit hard to use in the beginning, but once you connect them a few times, it works wonderfully.
If you need it (I don't), you can cut a filter mat and place it on the grille on top of the cylindrical part. The vacuum connection with it's grille should hold it in place properly.
Buy some flexible vacuum hose, cut to size and screw it in the adapters. Connect adapters, turn on your vacuum and that is it.
The receptacle holds a lot of material and if you use a transparent material, you can see when it is full. When full, just unlock the bayonett and empty it. If you want to use a bucket instead, you have to take a plastic paint bucket (it is critical that the lid seals well, otherwise the filter will not work) and screw the bucket adapter on the lid using 8 screws. You could use either M6 screws with nuts or self-tapping screws. After screwing it on, use a sharp knife to cut the hole in the lid under the adaptor and seal the outside of the adapter with some silicone to ensure a good seal.

title: Solid MeArm remix of RobotGeek 9G gripper

description.text:
Stop. It's the claw!

I didn't see the point in printing a bunch of flat parts for the RobotGeek 9G servo gripper but I really liked the design so I re-modelled the parts in Sketchup, stretched the fingers out getting rid of many support pieces and merged the plates into a single piece.

I also re-aligned the holes because I felt they were far too close together for the gripper gears to have the correct spacing between their teeth. I used M3 screws for everything, just use your best judgement and whatever is easiest - I just happened to have M3x15mm and M3x25mm lying around.

The back of the gripper has also been modified to be a drop in replacement for the MeArm's weak claw which can't even lift bro. One issue is that this gripper is a lot heavier than the standard one and its centre of gravity is much further forward which does necessitate having good servos in the rest of the arm.

This is a simple J-Head/groove mount for a Rostock platform and pneumatic fittings. The uploaded STLs are for 5 mm pneumatic fittings but this can be customized in Customizer. Many of the settings available in Customizer don't need to be (and probably shouldn't be) changed, just update "Pneumatic Fitting Drill Diameter" and "Pneumatic Fitting Thread Length" to the appropriate size. I had initially used and uploaded a variation of mattschoenholz's J-Head mount, however I found that it was unnecessarily complicated, made wiring difficult, and reduced the overall printable height. 25-Feb-2014 Update Support has been improved. Old support has been replaced with a spiral support that I've found much easier and cleaner to remove. Also in this update added support for double J-Heads. While I have not tried this configuration, it should work. Please let me know if you try it. 15-May-2014 Update I have recently been using this mount with a Hexagon Hot End with no issues. I've updated the title/description to be more widely applicable. No changes to the model.

The uploaded STLs are for a 0.35 mm layer width (nozzle size) and a 0.20 mm layer height; if you are printing with different settings then use Customizer (or modify the OpenSCAD file) to adjust accordingly. The layer width and height are only used for generating the support.  
Print both parts. I print the groove mount plate part with 100% infill, and the pneumatic fitting holder part with 20% infill and I have not had any problems.  
You will need to remove the spiral support from the bottom of the pneumatic fitting holder part. To do this I use some needle nose pliers and grab the center of the spiral and twist and it comes right out.  
You will also need to drill or cut out the hole for the pneumatic fitting. For smaller diameter holes use a drill bit of similar size, otherwise cut it out with a knife.

Hi!

I just finished my small project - upgrade UMO+ to my own designed 3D printer. Of course I tried to reuse all possible parts from UMO+, especial electronic parts and stepper motors. But I think it's also possible use the parts from other 3D Printers or just by it on Ali.

It will take some time to prepare all necessary information and printed parts to publishing.

What you need to have:

1) 20x20mm Alu Profiles with following sizes:

4 x 310mm
4 x 337.5mm (don't ask me why :) )
4 x 400mm

2) A lot of M3 8mm screws

3) Alu tubes (to hold 8mm shafts for X and Y axуs in place) with 8mm inner diameter and following lengths:

3 x 15.05 mm
2 x 12.7 mm
1 x 32.2 mm
1 x 13.4 mm
1 x 2.8 mm

What you need to print:

1) the files start with 'PART1' prefix - eight top corners for X and Y axis (actually the main parts of this design).

2) the files start with 'PART2' prefix - for the mounting of two Z shafts.
Attention: print the file 'PART2 - Z Bottom shaft connector left&right.stl' twice.

3) the files start with 'PART3' prefix - for the X, Y and Z motors mounting.

4) the files start with 'PART4' prefix - for X and Y end stop mounting.

5) the files start with 'PART5' prefix - for the bottom corners. The files need to be printed 4 times each.

6) the files start with "PART6' - extruder mount and other small stuff.

The parts from other people:

1) Ultimaker 1 Heated Bed Z-Stop https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:863389
2) E3D Ultimaker 2, 2+ Upgrade Conversion Kit https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1934309
3) ultimaker 2 fan duct 40mm e3d https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2062159
4) E3D-v6 Fan Duct https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:340312
5) TwisterBlocks https://www.youmagine.com/designs/twisterblocks

To be continue ...

We have a "Bosch Classixx" dishwasher here in the office that keeps on losing the wheels off the (bottom) dish rack.
I decided to model up a replacement (copying as closely as possible the original)
I will add a picture of the printed part when I can complete one. :)
EDIT: Source (Inventor) files added.

It should be possible to print these two parts and fit them together with little or no difficulty - the original was designed in such a way that it's almost impossible to dismantle without destroying the entire thing.
I have attempted to print both parts together but found that the castellations on the axle were printing too fast and just caused the printer to "blob" - hence the work in progress tag. I suppose I could add a sacrificial spigot on the Axle that would give it a base to adhere to the print bed.
EDIT: I successfully printed a set of two of each of these parts last night. Both the wheels came out okay; a little work should allow them to fit onto the axle with ease.
The Axles themselves need revising, the overhanging clip needed support material and the default "create support" setting in Slic3r doesn't work at all well (for me anyway). I think I might re-design the Inventor part to include support material - that way I can control exactly how it's created.
It has also got me thinking about creating better snap-off areas for this axle part.
Thoughts/comments are appreciated. :)

description.text: the lion sleeps tonight.

My daughter has to take a supplement everyday that comes in a giant capsule. Since there isn't a smaller dosage of it, I divided it up in to 4 smaller capsules. It was a giant pain in the rear to fill these tiny little capsules and get the dosage correct. So I did what any other person would do, I designed and printed my own custom tool that makes it easy and much faster to make them. Also it would be great to see a medical category added here on Thingaverse.  
This might be useful to anyone else that needs to fill capsules.

title: Enclosure for 5V Step Down Buck Converter from Banggood

description.text:
Designed this Enclosure for my Solar system. In this enclosure fits the Step-Down Converter Buck Module 5V from Banggood:

https://www.banggood.com/Step-Down-Converter-Buck-Module-DC-9V-40V-to-5V-4Porsts-USB-Charger-For-Navigation-Tablet-PC-Phone-p-1020893.html

I have not printed it yet. Was milled by a buddy with the CNC.

How i got to this?

Well, when I got this Module from Banggood, I first tested it with 4 Mobile phones. I see that it got very hot. I decided to stick a fan to it and glue it to my Solar charge controller. Now, half a year later, I decided to create an Enclosure because I rebuild my Solar system. After 3 Hours of designing how to place the Fan and Measuring everything so that it fits in the CNC (a tiny one), i came out with this.

Everything got so dusty while it runs.

description.text:
This is an ongoing project to decorate a wall next to my home office door, where I basically do all of my 3D printing jobs.

All models were designed with low poly.

Will add different marine creatures and objects from time to time.

Printer:

CreatBot DE Plus 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.06 - 0.3

Infill:

15 - 100

Notes:

You can vary the models scale to give them perspective. Also, you can use different infill patterns (without top layer) to give some kind of texture to certain models. This is what I did for the corals.

Glue on the Wall

I used simple home glue to stick the models on the wall. I can easily remove any model and clean the wall with a hot cloth if I want to.

Sail Ship

You can either print the whole ship using the (complete model file) or print it in parts using the separate files if you wish to have different colors for the hull, sails, flags.

To print the flags successfully since they are very small, make a total copies of 4 flags at least, print speed at 20mm/s, layer height (quality/resolution) not more than 0.06 and use 100% infill.

To scale up the separate files, make sure to that uniformly for the whole parts.

Glue the sails on the masts first.
Rim of 62 mm diameter by 29 of width with nut of 12mm

HI !

This is the final version of the front parts of the 28mm storm eagle

The pack for the rear of the ship is here :
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2487921

Parts list :

  • SE_front_bottom
  • SE_front_door
  • SE_front_gun (print 2x)
  • SE_front_gun_cover_V2
  • SE_front_land_pad (print 1+ 1mirrored)
  • SE_front_side (print 1 + 1 mirrored) (needs support only for the hinge)
  • SE_front_top
  • SE_front_turret (needs support)
  • SE_front_turret_axis
  • SE_canopy_final (needs support)
  • SE_pilot

Most parts don't need supports, and should be printable as oriented.

Note : I'm sorry for the LARGE files, I'm not good at optimizing models : /

Assembly is easy, I placed some centering pins on most parts.
for the canopy, please look in the images, you will find the pattern for cutting the "glass" in some clear plastic sheet (for example some laminating pouches will do fine).
You will also need some 1mm metal wire (for example from a paper clip) for the front door hinge.

Please share your makes :)
Have a nice print !

Copyright infringement is not intended. All parts are created freehand in 3d modeling software, no copyrighted product had been scanned or copied in any way.

title: Micro LED Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi there,

This is a little project to up-cycle some old batteries and learn more
on how to use FreeCAD.

Today we create a small micro LED lamp with parts I found when cleaning
up. :D

Requirements:

3 Batteries LR41. (other possible, see notes below)
1 LED
1 Improvised switch by using a metal part, a wire or folded aluminium
foil.

Tools:

3D Printer
Pliers (optional but recommended)

Requirement Notes:

I used metal from an old file for documents. It fit perfectly after
cutting to length.

When using a wire make sure the ends have proper contact. A
single core wire may work best due the fact it gives some spring
effect to the switch.

Using folded aluminium foil may not give the best results.
Adding some paper to fold around may add some more spring effect.
This is totally untested, but works for sure.

You may need to decrease the "roof" of the battery compartment to
gain enough space for the switch design of your choice. However
you can rasp it down to your needs without printing easily.

Printing:

This thing is tiny and the supports may cause trouble. The small
gaps between the battery compartment are required. The one in
the back is to get the metal part through. The first one to be
able to pop out the batteries and fit the LED.

I printed it upside down, but you may want it in any other
direction. The nice part of this project is that it does not
require a lot of plastic, so you learn about the capabilities
of your printer, too. Because of the fragile components it may
also be wise to print at high quality. Again, the part barley
needs any plastic.

Make sure your printer is calibrated or you may get a to small or
to big part.

Assembly:

Assembly is actually the hard part. Since there is no battery
cover, I designed the lamp to be a tight fit. Prepare the LED
first. Easiest way is to place the LED onto the ledge of the
printed part where it will be mounted. Cut the wire without
the goblet (cathode) so it hits the case. Now bend the one
with the goblet (anode) 90 degree inwards and cut it like
shown in the pictures.

Insert the bended LED wire using the gab under the "roof" of
the battery compartment. If done right the LED holds itself
and the small ledge of the printed part will fit perfect
between the LEDs wires. Now insert the batteries with the plus
side facing the LED. Make sure the first battery hits the LED
wire with the front side. Along with the last battery put the
metal part or wire into place and bend the other side, to just
not connect to the other LED wire.

You may need pliers to push the batteries in place. Trust me
they will jump around a few times until everything is in place,
but once you are finished everything is rock solid.

If done correct you just need to push the metal, wire, aluminium
and the LED lights up. If the spring effect is big enough the
"switch" should open the circuit once you stop pushing it.

Notes:

Even though this is just for LR41, you may change the sketch of
the LED lamp to fit any other battery at your disposal.

Since I am still a beginner with FreeCAD the included file may
have some issues, so please don´t blame me. This project only
exists to learn how to design parts and instead of creating
useless cubes or other stuff, I want to create actual
functional parts as kind of reward for myself.

Happy Printing

Anet A8

Rotate the object so it fits the capabilities of your printer. The supports are quite tricky as gabs needed are closed by support.

Printing on the side or upside down should work best.

print_settings.Notes:: Take care with the setup of the details. They are not easy to print.

description.text:
A set of modified parts for the hackable Guardian model.

The first Modification is a bottom lid that is easy to open and that does not fully block access for cables to the leg joints. Instead of a place for a switch it has 3 mountpoints/cable holes. I added a servo mounting bracket inspired by the Adafruid lid (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2441788) but removed some unneeded plastic that does nothing for the functioning of the bracket and only causes problems for you if you use a slightly different stepper (mine was 1mm deeper so the lid would not close properly).

The Second is a set of modified "details" for the head and body. I cut those apart, rotated them and added legs that need to be removed after printing. Like this they are still hard to print but not impossible anymore. With these you can print the body/head in a different plastic than the details and paint them separately. I am using this to print the body/head in translucent PLA while having non-translucent details.

The Third is a modification of the Leg segments. I fused the segments together for better bed adhesion and strengthened a part that tended to break upon assembly at least for the PLA segments I made. This will also slight restrict movement so they don't lever apart as easy. To assemble them you will need hot water and be quick about it ;)

Note: I haven't added the body details yet since I haven't tested them yet.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Genius WideCam F100

This Cam is simply amazing!

Checklist:

  • Camera works without Powered HUB
  • FullHD
  • HD Ready
  • Wide Angle view so smaller resolution makes good pics
  • Good quality in low light settings!
  • Focus with manual wheel!
  • Good Price

You can mount the camera holer onto the round pillar directly or dismantle the cam and use the raw cam holder.

If you are satisfied with the angle glue the Cam mount stabilizer to the pillar and the arm to make it more sturdy.

My options in the pic:

camera_usb_options="-r 1024x720 -fourcc RGBP -q 95"

Please be aware that if you use the -f handle, that YUYV format is used.

Other options that are known to work:

-r 1920x1080 -f 30 gives full 16:9 frame @30fps
-r 1920x1080 -f 5 -y gives full 16:9 frame @5fps
-r 1280x720 -f 30 gives full 16:9 frame @30fps
-r 1280x720 -f 8 -y gives full 16:9 frame @8fps
-r 800x600 -f 30 gives cropped 4:3 frame @30fps
-r 800x600 -f 10 -y gives cropped 4:3 frame @10fps
Lower resolutions 640x360 , 352x288, 320x240, 176x144, 160x120 all operate at -f 30 both for MJPG as well as YUYV format.

See: https://github.com/foosel/OctoPrint/wiki/Webcams-known-to-work

PS: I did not focus the cam 100% correct for now. There is better quality possible. Especially if you use 1080p resolution with the cam.

Amazon Link: https://www.amazon.de/Genius-32200213101-F100-Widecam/dp/B0080CE5M4/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1505652822&sr=8-1&keywords=Genius+WideCam+F100

author: alesandrinho90

description.text:
The WorkBee is our latest CNC Machine and is a culmination of all our experience, feedback, and suggestions from selling the OX CNC Machine over the past 2 years. The WorkBee is capable of accurately cutting foams, woods, plastics or aluminum at depths greater than 25mm to 0.2mm accuracy or greater.

The main request we got for the OX was for a lead screw driven version. The WorkBee CNC Machine has been designed from the ground up to incorporate this and more. One issue with switching to a Screw driven system is that it would be limited in size to 1000x1000mm. This size limitation was not acceptable, so we have dual designed the WorkBee so it can be screw or belt driven. If the WorkBee CNC Kit is belt driven it can be made larger than 1000x1000mm. The WorkBee CNC Machine can be converted between the two, as the overall design is exactly the same for both.

The WorkBee makes full use of the V-Slot Extrusion system. On the X and Y Axis C-Beam extrusions are used. The C-Beam profile is stronger and allows the drive systems to be concealed from debris. For the belt driven setup, a new belt and pinion setup has been developed that fits inside the 'C' channel on the Y-Axis extrusions.

Like on the OX we have made a complete written instruction manual, with IKEA'eske assembly diagrams. This covers the mechanical assembly and electronics setup. (These will be completed soon... )

The Appendix of the instruction manual has a full parts list for the standard 750 x 750mm WorkBee. A excel file is also provided for the standard size. For a bigger version, only the V-Slot, ACME Lead Screws, GT3 Belts, and number of spoiler board supports is different. The standard size, includes the parts list for one spoiler board support. If you plan to go bigger or smaller, the section below will help you to buy the correct extrusions.

We designed this kit due to the number of requests for modifications of our OX CNC Machine Kit. We are offering a Full Kit, Mechanical Kit, Plates Kit and various add-on kits on our website. These kits can be found by following this link: http://ooznest.co.uk/3D-Printer-CNC-Kits-Bundles/WorkBee-CNC-Machine

Lots and lots of the parts on the machine come direct from Openbuildspartstore. Therefore, you can be sure you are supporting them :). Full disclosure, the extrusions are now manufactured by us in the UK, but this was due to it becoming unfeasible to ship the quantities we need from Openbuilds in the US anymore.

We would like to give a big thank you to Mark Carew and Openbuilds for designing an excellent V-Slot system, which they have allowed to be freely shared, remixed, and sold. We would also like to thank the Openbuilds and wider community for sharing their designs that make the builds keeping getting better and better.

comments.text:
You always get people arguing about the anti z wobble.
For one the Creality CR10 Comes with Bracket with a bearing at the top, where the lead screw goes, Very similar to another Anet A6 anti z wobble with a bearing found here on Thingiverse.
If your lead screw is perfectly straight then they are perfectly fine, but if your lead screw is bent this will make matters worse.
I know this because I had them fitted to my Anet A6 and it helped a lot, but as soon as one of my rods got bent slightly they made things worse.
So I changed them over to Dust caps for z rods on the Anet a6.
comments.author: Dazfx81

comments.text: Leadscrews should not be constrained on the top,. there's a reason the hole is bigger!!!   This has been covered many times before.
comments.author: STIG_

comments.text: Exactly. If the leadscrew will be constrained in the top it will create a wobble in the nut. The nut will warp the tiny Anet vertical rails on every rotation. Leadscrew vertical end has to be free until you have rock solid vertical rails in your printer.

description.text:
This is a remix of Loubie's Squizzle fitted for a LED inside the acorn. To put the LED in, you should pause the print at around 80mm (assuming you're printing full scale), insert the wires inside the tube and properly fix the LED in the acorn so that it won't move (a dab of hot glue should do the trick). You then hit continue and let the print finish. After it's complete you remove the print from the build plate, you properly adjust the LED's wires and insert a 2032 coin battery in the slot at the bottom. If your wires make proper contact the acorn should light up.

This is still a work in progress.

description.text:
5x8 Oldham coupler for NEMA17 steppers on 8mm lead screws.
Length 30mm, diameter 20mm.

There is surprisingly very little play, and the assembly slides smoothly.

Some action : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nWa5ihTXM7E

Print with no additional brim or supports (required supports are part of the STL) : https://youtu.be/RKpWhwiRadc

The dual clamp version is preferred, as the grub screw solution gives too much hassle.
If you have already printed it, an upgrade STL is available to print replacement motor-side parts.

BOM :

  • 4 M3x12mm bolts and assorted nuts (2 for the single clamp version).
  • A M3 grub screw on the 5mm side (only for the single clamp version).
  • Lithium grease, or any kind of fluid but thick grease

Post print :

  • Grind the parts by sliding them against one an other. And as the assembly will take an affinity in a specific layout, trace a mounting mark with a soft-tip pen.
  • Top/bottom orientation of the central part can be identfied by the direction of the surface lines inside de slits : oblique on the top side, straight under the bridge .
  • Cut the 8mm clamp(s) away from its(their) support grid, don't bother removing the grid as it helps keeping the collet straight against the assembly.
  • Apply a generous amount of grease on the sufaces and slits before use.
  • Leave a slight play (less than 1mm). Adjustment can be made by sliding either side.

As a matter of fact, it won't be able to hold any weight and has to be used with bearings / thrust bearings

For the Tevo Tarantula see this for the Z axis : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2379659
as well as this spacer printed with a 10mm thickness : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26126

comments.text: Thanks for the design ndupont! I just printed one up and plan on installing it tonight! Just to clarify, when you say there should be 1mm of play, is that as between the slits? comments.text:
Hi, the play is between the parts. The middle part has to have some play between the large flat surfaces.
On the other hand, slits will be quite fit at the beginning, and tend to get some non-detrimental play after months of use.
