title: Tournaments Awards / Plaque / Trophy - Laser Cut 0.20in Clear Acrylic and a 3D Printed Base

description.text:
I happen to have a laser cutter and a 3D printer. I also happen to participate in many tournaments for board games and wargames. It is always nice to be able to create a nice award for a tournament, especially if you do not break the bank to produce it. Tournament organizers volunteer so much of their time to make sure you have fun that an award is the least that we can do.

I normally edit the template files attached in Corel Draw or Adobe Illustrator. Then I engrave and cut on the laser (suggestions on the print settings portion). I cut them in 0.200 clear acrylic from Home Depot. For about $20-30, you can cut about 18 awards (assuming no errors). You find the material on the same area where they sell windows and screens.

The base is 3D printed, and you can adapt it if you want - the OpenSCAD file should be there.

If you do not have the equipment to make this, there are providers on the internet that will help you laser cut this. A partner of mine is great at laser cutting - One Eyed Raven Design. I can also help you (contact me on my etsy store).

Sistema de nivelamento da mesa de impressão com molas para impressora 3D Stella.


Esta é uma alternativa para que não precise fazer pequenos nivelamentos via software. É bem mais rápido e fácil.

OBS: Se sua impressora ainda está na garantia, consulte o suporte para verificar se não vai perder garantia.

OBS2: A peça que segura o espelho foi feita para o espelho original dela que tem espessura de 3mm.

OBS3: Após colocar esse kit na sua impressora 3D Stella, será necessário fazer o nivelamento conforme manual fornecido pelo suporte técnico (está no forum dos Stelleiros).

Lista de materiais:

  1. 4x parafusos M3x20 (Se puder ser cabeça cilíndrica, melhor)
  2. 2xporcas
  3. 4x molas (Caso tenha dificuldade de encontrar para comprar, você pode encontrar pregadores de roupa que possuem mola, foi o que fiz. Crédito da ideia: Glauco Nicodemus)
  4. 1x extension_left
  5. 1x extension_right
  6. 4x mirror_clip
  7. 2x front_elevator
  8. 2x back_elevator

Os elevadores usam a roda que já vem na Stella. Para prender o extensor na estrutura, pode utilizar os parafusos da própria Stella com as porcas citadas na lista de materiais acima.

Após a impressão, para nivelar, basta girar a roda que prende o parafuso embaixo para que consiga elevar ou abaixar cada ponto.

Since I never carrycoins with me I decided to print some replacements to use for Shopping Carts. They have the same dimensions of real coins but have a notch to attach to a keychain.

Only 0.50EUR, 1EUR and 2EUR are available for now, but if people want more I can easily add them. Of course you can make your own pretty easily. Read the "How I Designed This" to make your own with Fusion 360.

Finding the dimensions

Just google "1 euro dimensions" or "1 usd dimensions" and you'll find the dimensions you're looking for.

Basic sketch

In Fusion 360, draw two circles with the respective centers 25mm apart. One circle should be the same diameter as the coin (adjust for your printer if needed) and the other one 5mm or thereabouts. Then add a "Point to Point" Slot between the two centers with 7mm size.
Optionally, you can add some text to the center of the coin or some decorations.

Extrude and decorate

Extrude everything (except the hole) the same height as the coin you wish to reproduce. Then pick the sides that join the Coin with the slot and add some fillets.

Print

Print. I suggest going 100% Infill and as small layer height as you can. This way you'll have consistent size reproduction and a sturdy keychain.

title: D-Bot Fully-Supported Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a from-scratch redesign of the D-Bot extruder. I'd had issues with high filament pressure when printing very quickly causing the filament to bow out and either break or wrap around the hobbed gear, plus I want the option to use softer filaments with the D-bot.

This extruder design keeps PTFE support tubes in very close proximity to the bearing and hobbed wheel, so there's no possibility of filament bending out of the extrusion path.

The hardware needed to assemble it is pretty basic:

MK8 extruder gear (from the stock extruder)
625ZZ bearing (from stock extruder)
3x M3 8mm bolts (from stock extruder)
6 M3 washers
3x M3 30mm bolts
2x M3 nuts
Small length of 4mm OD/2mm ID PTFE tubing
2x M3-sized tensioner springs. (There are good options in the set of springs from Home Depot that is called out in the D-Bot parts list -- generally you want a somewhat stronger, small spring about 5mm in diameter, 20mm long, so it can compress down to 12-13mm)
Bowden connector (from the stock extruder)
1x M5 10mm bolt (same as all the small bolts in the D-bot)

Assembly should be pretty straightford. After printing the parts, insert the two captive M3 nuts first. The holes are small, you may need to work on them a bit with a hobby knife to get the nuts in depending on the tolerances of your printer. Its meant to be tight, and it took some fiddling, but I got them all in.

Cut some small lengths of the PTFE tubing and insert them from the outside inwards in the filament channel. The one that goes under the Bowden connector needs to be flush to the plastic inside the opening, so its pretty short. I was able to seat it using a hex bolt head to push it in place. Twisting can help. If its too tight, run an M4 screw through the holes and use it to bore them out to a true 4mm. Once the tubing is seated, cut the inner edges flush with the two curved surfaces with a fine hobby knife.This is important, its the proximity of the tubing to the moving parts that keeps the filament in alignment.

After that, screw the bowden connector in, and then bolt the stepper to the bracket using the three 8mm M3 bolts. The screw closest to the bowden connector (which has no inset) is left out.

Attach the bearing to the tension arm with the M5 10mm bolt. Use one of the 30mm M3 bolts, with a washer on each side, to run through the tension arm and screw into the stepper and main bracket.

The tension is maintained with the other two M3 30mm bolts -- assemble each with a washer, the spring, and another washer, and then screw into the holes on the tension arm. Adjust the screws for the amount of tension you want, I've found 12-13mm seems "about right".

My printer is dual extrusion, with one extruder on the left and one on the right, so there's versions for either side uploaded. You only need to print the two parts for the side you want.

Printer:

D-Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Most of the parts on my D-bot were printed with PETG, but these don't have a lot of strain on them, nor are they near any heat, so I printed them with PLA because the prints end up more precise and the holes are pretty precise. I'm sure you could print it with ABS or PETG, as well.

You'll need supports because of the inset for the stepper motor on the rear, and the bowden connector. I strongly recommend printing with supports only on the bed -- the filament path and other holes shouldn't need supports and it'll be a real pain to dig the supports out if you print them with them.

This is a deliberately short and simple tabletop game intended to teach small children the basics of board games. My son’s developmental pediatrician suggested simple board games to practice sharing, rules, and turns.

In this game, players take turns rolling a six-sided die to move across the board. Once an ‘obstacle tile’ is reached, the player stops and immediately rolls again to try and meet the requirement of the obstacle. If successful, the player advances the number of tiles equal to the success roll, all still in the same turn. A roll that fails to reach an obstacle, or meet an obstacle’s requirement, ends the turn.

The three ‘obstacle tiles’ are of incrementing difficulty and should be placed that way when creating the board. The mountain tile should be encountered first. It requires a roll greater than 3 to pass. The forest tile should be encountered second. It can be passed by rolling 2 or 4. The dragon tile is last, requiring a 6 to pass. The ending game tile should be 6 or less tiles beyond the dragon.

Instead of painting, I use sugar, or flour to fill in the number cavities of each obstacle tile.

We are playing with some Dutchmogul minis, printed at 28mm scale.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1394097
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1394139

A special thanks to Loubie, Nevaneva, Gluetolf and JAWong for the dragon, tail, mountain and trees. Because of you, making this game required very little effort.

This printer was designed from the ground up with the goal in mind to be mechanical robust, to operate quiet and integrate into enviroments out of a workshop.

This project is still in progress but I think its time to share it and maybe get some constructive criticism or inspire others with the concept.

Some key facts:

  • Build volume: 340 x 240 x 220mm (theoretical)
  • E3D Titan / Lite6 / Volcano with 0.6/0.8 nozzles for fast and strong parts
  • MGN12 linear rails
  • 24V / MKS Gen V1.4
  • TMC2100 from Watterott for all steppers

UPDATE Jan2018:

  • Big 75x30mm radial fan (probably overkill, waiting on an 75x15mm one)
  • Closed extruder design
  • Ribbon cable for clean looks and modularity (20Pin Dupont 2.54)
  • Octoprint with webcam
  • TMC2208 for X and Y axis

Feel free to share!

Cheers, Pascal

(Maybe at some time I will make a little build documentation)

comments.text: Good looking machine! I like the simplicity. Have you had any issues with the crossing belt configuration? Do the four Z screws bind at all? Are they all run from a single stepper? Have you tested speeds?

Thanks! No, crossing the belts enables them to get nice and low and in one plane. I only have 2 Z screws and they a wired in parallel to one tmc2100 stepper.
My focus is more on silent operation then on speed, so normally I print with 60-80mm/s but with the 0.6 nozzle thats plenty enough ;)

description.text: This is a case for the TP-Link TL-WR703N router with an additional open source expansion board which adds on a USB Hub for a total of 3 USB ports available, a FTDI 2232 chip with 10GPIO broken out as well as the MPSSE pins for serial/JTAG/I2C/SPI etc. i.e. this would make a great low cost/low power robotics controller. Measurements derived from original case, with a change to a slide in arrangement to house the expansion board with the case acting as a board spacer as well. Blog post with firmware ROMs and HOWTOs will be made available on http://www.madox.net/blog/tp-link-tl-wr703n/ shortly. The OSHW expansion board details for the TL-WR703N is available here :- http://www.kean.com.au/oshw/WR703N/

WARNING/NOTE : The recessed USB port does not have an opening with this case. The intention is that a really short USB flash drive could be used there. Update : The tp-wr703n_kean_v2_A2.stl file has an extended portion that protects the protruding USB as well as giving extra space for the USB flash drive [tested with Sandisk Cruzer Fit mini] Print both files. Note orientation of the "A" part might need to be rotated to avoid supports ['base' to the bottom]. Slide in router + expansion board combo gently.
Take care on the front USB to ensure it goes into the hole. Attach the 'cover' and secure with 2 M3x4/6/8/10/12 countersunk screws [Length doesn't really matter].

description.text: Name tag for our first grand daughter This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/9S0QgC8UPPa

Mount for the Boogie Board 8.5" LCD eWriter.

I've been using a Boogie Board for quite a while to keep track of misc data, leave notes about where and why I'm out of the office, etc for a long time. The problem is that the board tends to.... wander....

So to make it more usable (less prone to wandering), I designed a simple mount.

Basically, this mount allows the board to sit at 45 degrees on the edge of a piece of plywood, and it's secured by 2 small wood screws. My desk is made up of plywood 25mm thick, but I've included the SketchUp file in case you need to modify that.

Depending on your printer you may either have to file/sand the board clips to fit, or you could modify the file for a little more clearance. You could probably scale the file by 1 or 2 %, but that will also affect the plywood mount area as well.

I printed this in PETG, but that's only because I mostly print in that now. I suspect it would work just as well in PLA. I used 15% infill, 3 perimeters and 3 layers, but those are just my defaults.

Printer:

Anycubic Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15
Designed in SketchUp Pro 2017.

This is my best attempt to slim the width of my X Carriage by moving the radial blowers closer to the heat sink and orienting them to blow on the part from the front. This design also afforded me the space to put a mounting plate for the SN-04 Probe (possibly others) in front of everything which will make finer adjustments a lot easier. I realize that the blower output is offset from the nozzle, but if you can believe, it is much closer to the nozzle than I had prior. I do hope someone can remix this to include ducts to direct airflow right to the nozzles.

comments.text: After getting everything together and proceeding to bring the SN-04 probe to the front, I then realized it would be about 80mm+ in front of the nozzles.  That was my Homer Simpson (((DOOOOOOOOPE))) momement.  That aside though, let me be a lesson, (that I can't believe didn't yet personally sink in) that you gotta look deeper at some Thingiverse things.  A month ago, I started adding upgrades to my spider and it seems that every single thing I add to it, it somehow unearths at least 1 (usually more) mechanical problem that needs to be resolved otherwise foreseeable failure becomes imminent.

description.text:
This is a collection of things I created for my build of SCOTT_3Ds great Hypercube Evolution (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2254103).

3030_Lack_Foot.stl is a foot which fits 30x30 extrusions and allows mounting the printer. It's intended to mount the printer on an IKEA Lack table. A 300x300 build platform size hypercube fits well on a Lack table.

CableGuideClip.stl is a CableGuide which fits onto Bosch Style 3030 extrusions.

SBASE_Mount.stl can be used to mount an MKS Sbase (1.3) on a flat surface, in my case the top of the Lack table.

MOSFET Mount.stl is a mount for my mosfet board.

Shunt_Mount.stl is a mount for the shunt used by my power meter.

LED_Mount is a mount for motor bike daytime running lamps (see picture). The thread measures 9.5mm x 20mm (see picture of LED and mounted on the HEVO). The lights can be screwed into the mount and the cable comes out at the back. The angle of the LED is designed for the mounts to be placed on the top extrusions close to the corners.

title: All in one Battery and Tank Holder/charger

description.text:
This is a 18650 battery compartment, compact and easy to print. 4 holes are included to insert the charger's contacts, so the last 2 batteries will be charged. They are also included on the sides 2 tank containers, each can accommodate a 22mm or 25mm tank, convenient when you need to fill them up!
The model is designed to be printed without support, except for the two square blocks on the sides.
Then I will also add the lower part to hold the battery charger electronics.
Full print video and test operation
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y60cqsL0COQ

The 4 holes are made with simple paper clips, inserted into the 4 holes and bent slightly. These should be properly connected to the contacts of the lithium battery charger circuit, not to a mobile charger! If you do not know lithium batteries or you do not intend to use electronics, I recommend using this project as a convenient stand!

title: Display stand for Sierpinski octahedron / octahedron flake

description.text:
If you print ricktu's fractal pyramid twice and stick them together, you obtain a full Sierpinski octahedron or octahedron flake.
I created a little display stand based on the fractal pyramid itself, that allows to display your octahedron in upright position.

Unlike the pyramid, this cannot print in spiral (vase) mode because it consists of 4 separate pyramids. However, you can still easily print this with just one contour and no infill. Just ensure that the lower 0.8mm are printed solid. (E.g. when printing in 0.2mm layers, enforce 4 bottom layers.)

description.text:
Amino 125 STB Wall Mount

The Amino 125 STB is a device that takes a digital media stream and converts it into an analog output for use on a TV or other display. The 125 is an older device, but you can read about them here:
https://www.aminocom.com/

(I have no association with these guys, I just use their stuff as part of my job)

The 125 was designed more for home or office use, and not the industrial type setting that I'm using them in. So the "stand/mount" that comes with them is all but useless to me (the black thing holding the 125 upright). Unfortunately, there really isn't a good way to attach this curved device to a flat surface. So I set out to design a mount for them.

The inspiration for this mount comes from a really nice design by MaximSachs:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:292822

I'm not sure I should call it a remix since I butchered that design so much, but he gets the credit for the inspiration of this mount.

There are 4 parts to the mount:

  1. Wall mount (red)
  2. Cable brace (orange)
  3. Lower mount (blue)
  4. Upper mount (green)

Basically, you screw the Wall Mount to the wall, place the Cable Brace over the mount, use the Lower Mount to secure the Cable Brace in place, and then attach the Upper Mount. Then the 125 slides into place. Plug everything in and secure the cables to the Cable Brace using zip ties (zip tie slots built in to the brace)

It sounds more complicated than it is. Once you have all the pieces printed, you'll see how everything dovetails together.

I only use this mount in a vertical position, so gravity and friction hold everything together. If you use it some other way, you should probably add a drop of glue to hold things in place. BUT don't use more than a drop. The wall mount screw holes are covered by the upper and lower mounts. If they are glued in place, you can remove the screws....

I've used a small sliver of paper wedged in to add friction to things before....

Notes:

Printed in PETG, but PLA would probably work. 3 perimeters and 3 layers, but these are just my defaults.

The wall mount and cable brace will print without support. Print on their backs.

Rotate the Lower mount so that square hole is down. You will need a small amount of support under the dovetail.

Rotate the Upper mount with the entire flat side down. If you print it right side up, you'll need support under the dovetail.

description.text: A simple Nozzle display, very compact (credit card size) It allows you to store up to 50 6mm nozzles, E3D compatible, including longer Volcano ones. There's 10 columns labeled 0.1 ; 0.25 ; 0.3 ; 0.4 ; 0.5 ; 0.6 ; 0.8 ; 1 ; 1.2 and 1.4mm, with 5 spaces for each column. Each column is curved for easy pickup. The display can be used flat or standing at an angle to provide any nozzle messy fall !
